body_html:
I am not aware of CUDA 9.0 being deprecated. You can run the latest cuDNN with the prebuilt binary, e.g. 7.1.5, the docker container (linux) has tensorflow compiled with cuDNN 7.0 and ships with 7.1 binary.

Can you indicate what is not stable about CUDA 9.0 and what you mean by "starts to reject"? I have been running CUDA 9.0 on the NVIDIA DGX-1 with the 396.x driver and if anything it is much faster that with earlier drivers if you have updated cuDNN. Of course that is not windows. I do not run on windows myself but I am curious of the use case and have you tried to compile with 9.2 and the problem went away? If moving to CUDA 9.2 makes the windows experience better it may be something we can consider but I do not plan to push for CUDA 9.2 on Linux as currently there is very little to gain and 9.0 has been stable for linux.

Thank you for the information.

I am not aware of CUDA 9.0 being deprecated.  You can run the latest cuDNN with the prebuilt binary, e.g. 7.1.5, the docker container (linux) has tensorflow compiled with cuDNN 7.0 and ships with 7.1 binary.

Can you indicate what is not stable about CUDA 9.0 and what you mean by "starts to reject"? I have been running CUDA 9.0 on the NVIDIA DGX-1 with the 396.x driver and if anything it is much faster that with earlier drivers if you have updated cuDNN.  Of course that is not windows. I do not run on windows myself but I am curious of the use case and have you tried to compile with 9.2 and the problem went away?  If moving to CUDA 9.2 makes the windows experience better it may be something we can consider but I do not plan to push for CUDA 9.2 on Linux as currently there is very little to gain and 9.0 has been stable for linux.

Thank you for the information.
